title: Option to disable search highlighting from updating PRIMARY selection (Linux/X11 & Wayland)
body:
## Description
On Linux systems, VSCode’s search highlighting automatically updates the PRIMARY selection buffer replacing whatever was previously selected with the mouse in any application. This differs from most native Linux applications (e.g. Kate, gedit, Sublime Text) where search highlighting is purely visual and does **not** change the PRIMARY selection.

This behaviour causes problems when using PRIMARY for middle-click paste since searching in VSCode overwrites the buffer without explicit user interaction.

---

## Steps to reproduce (X11 or Wayland + Klipper)
1. Open another app (e.g., Kate) and select text with the mouse — it becomes the PRIMARY selection.
2. Switch to VSCode.
3. Press `Ctrl+F` and search for a word.
4. The first match is highlighted.
5. Middle-click paste in another application.

**Actual:**
The pasted text is the VSCode search match and not the text previously selected in Kate.

**Expected:**
Search highlighting in VSCode should be visual-only and **not** update the PRIMARY selection unless the user explicitly selects the text.

---

## Environment
- VSCode version: 1.103.0 
- Electron: 37.2.3
- OS: KDE Plasma 5.27.12, Kubuntu, X11 session (also reproducible on Wayland)
- Clipboard manager: Klipper (KDE clipboard)

---

## Suggested solution
Introduce a user-configurable setting, for example:

```json
"editor.find.updatePrimarySelection": false
```

When set to false programmatic highlights (e.g. search matches) should not modify the PRIMARY selection buffer.

## Additional context

PRIMARY selection behaviour is an X11/Wayland feature and is widely used for mouse-based copy/paste workflows.

Other editors like Kate, gedit, and Sublime Text maintain the PRIMARY buffer only on explicit user selections.

This behaviour affects both X11 and Wayland sessions if VSCode runs under XWayland.

title: Feature 5: Spec Functionality: Allow for Continuous Editing and Synchronization of Specification Files
body:
The specification files (requirements.md, design.md, tasks.md) should not be static. The functionality should allow for a dynamic lifecycle:

    Chat-based Refinement: The user should be able to ask the AI assistant via chat to make changes or add new items to the specification documents.

    Manual Editing: The user should be able to manually edit the Markdown files, and the AI assistant should be able to understand these changes.

    Code-to-Spec Synchronization: There should be a way to keep the specifications synchronized with the code. For example, after implementing a task, the developer could ask the assistant to update the spec to reflect the final code, or vice-versa, ensuring the documentation never becomes outdated.

Ref: #261159 , #261160 , #261162 , #261163

title: Feature 4: Spec Functionality: Automatic Generation of tasks.md with an Actionable and Trackable Implementation Plan
body:
Based on the requirements.md and design.md files, the AI assistant should generate a tasks.md file that details the implementation plan. This file should contain:

    Task List: A list of discrete and well-defined tasks and sub-tasks.

    Dependency Ordering: Tasks should be correctly sequenced, respecting their dependencies.

    Link to Requirements: Each task should be clearly linked to the corresponding requirements and acceptance criteria in requirements.md.

    Implementation Details: Tasks should include details such as the need for unit tests, integration tests, loading states, and responsiveness and accessibility requirements.

This creates a clear roadmap for developers, allowing for precise progress tracking.

Ref: #261159 , #261160 , #261162

title: Feature 3: Spec Functionality: Automatic Generation of design.md with Codebase Analysis and Architecture Proposal
body:
The AI assistant should be able to generate a technical design document (design.md) that not only suggests an architecture but also takes the existing project source code into account. The generated file should include:

    Code Analysis: The ability to analyze the current codebase to understand existing technologies, patterns, and structures.

    Architecture Diagrams: Generation of data flow diagrams (e.g., using Mermaid.js) to visualize the interaction between components.

    Interface Definitions: Proposals for interfaces (e.g., TypeScript), data models, and database schemas.

    Strategies: Suggestions for error handling and unit testing strategies.

This ensures that the new feature is designed consistently with the rest of the application.

Ref: #261159 , #261160

title: Allow terminal sticky scroll only when rich shell integration
body:
Terminal sticky scroll was being enabled whenever any command detection capability existed, even when shell integration wasn't working properly. This led to poor user experience when shells didn't emit the proper `133;C` sequences or when shell integration was only partially functional.

The image shows a terminal where sticky scroll might appear inconsistently or not work correctly due to incomplete shell integration - the shell is showing basic output but may not be emitting the full set of shell integration sequences that sticky scroll relies on for proper functionality.

This change ensures sticky scroll only activates when rich shell integration is fully enabled by:

1. **Adding `hasRichCommandDetection` check**: The `_shouldBeEnabled()` method now requires `capability.hasRichCommandDetection` to be `true`, ensuring the shell is properly emitting `OSC 133;C` sequences and other rich integration features.

2. **Dynamic event handling**: Added `_richCommandDetectionListeners` to listen for changes in rich command detection status, so sticky scroll can be enabled/disabled dynamically as shell integration status changes during a terminal session.

**Before**: Sticky scroll enabled with any command detection → inconsistent behavior  
**After**: Sticky scroll only enabled with rich shell integration → reliable experience

The fix is minimal (13 lines) and follows existing code patterns while ensuring users only see sticky scroll when it will work reliably.

Fixes #244151.

title: Feature 2: Spec Functionality: Automatic Generation of requirements.md with User Stories and Acceptance Criteria in EARS Notation
body:
Expanding on the spec generation feature, the AI assistant should specialize in creating the requirements.md file in a structured manner. It should be able to:

    Convert the feature description into multiple user stories.

    For each user story, generate clear and testable acceptance criteria.

    Utilize the EARS (Easy Approach to Requirements Syntax) notation, which follows the pattern "WHEN [condition/event], THE SYSTEM SHALL [expected behavior]".

This makes the requirements less ambiguous, easier to test, and ensures that edge cases are considered from the outset.

Ref: #261159

title: Feature 1: Automatic Generation of Specification Documents from a Description
body:
**This issue basically consists of breaking down tasks in another issue that I created here it is: [issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260720) and that was requested by a member of the github team, I will put all the other interconnected features here while I edit and put them here for you to track them correctly!**

Similar to Kiro, VS Code should have an AI assistant capable of taking a high-level feature description (e.g., "create a product review system") and, from it, automatically generate an initial specification structure in Markdown files.

This functionality would create three main files:

    requirements.md: For user requirements.

    design.md: For the technical architecture.

    tasks.md: For the detailed implementation plan.

This would serve as the starting point for development, ensuring the initial vision is translated into an organized structure before any code is written.

Features list: 

Feature 1: This Issue;
Feature 2: #261160 
Feature 3: #261162 
Feature 4: #261163 
Feature 5: #261164 

Future reference if you have any further questions about this, regarding all 5 features, can be found here:
[spec doc](https://kiro.dev/docs/specs/concepts/)

title: Open with Code" option missing from File Explorer after update to version  1.103

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
- VS Code Version: 1.103
- OS Version: Windows 11 

**Issue:**
After updating to the latest VS Code version, the "Open with Code" right-click context menu option is no longer available in File Explorer.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Update VS Code to the latest version.
2. Open File Explorer.
3. Right-click on any file or folder.
4. Observe that the "Open with Code" or "Open with VS Code" option is missing.

**Expected Behavior:**
The right-click context menu should include the "Open with Code" option for files and folders.

**What I Have Tried:**
- Enabled “Explorer: Context Menu” in VS Code settings.
- Restarted PC.
- Uninstalled and reinstalled VS Code (latest stable build).
- Checked `Shell Command: Install 'code' command in PATH`.
- Verified that the issue persists even after clean installation.

title: Implement inline rename functionality for chat sessions
body:
This PR implements inline rename functionality for chat sessions following VS Code's established file explorer pattern, replacing the previous popup dialog approach based on user feedback.

## Key Features

**Inline Editing**: Chat session names are now edited directly in the tree view, similar to how file renaming works in VS Code's explorer. When you press F2 or select "Rename" from the context menu, the session name becomes an editable input field in-place.

**Real-time Validation**: Input validation happens as you type, with error messages displayed inline for empty names or names exceeding 100 characters.

**Keyboard Shortcuts**: 
- **F2**: Start rename (when session is focused)
- **Enter**: Save changes
- **Escape**: Cancel editing

**Auto-focus and Selection**: When rename starts, the input field automatically receives focus and all text is pre-selected for easy editing.

**Blur Handling**: Changes are automatically saved when clicking away from the input field.

## Implementation Details

The implementation follows VS Code's architectural patterns:

- **`IChatSessionEditableData`**: Interface similar to VS Code's `IEditableData` for managing inline editing state
- **`ChatSessionRenameService`**: Singleton service to track which session is being edited
- **Enhanced Renderer**: `SessionsRenderer` detects editable state and switches between normal display and inline editing modes
- **InputBox Integration**: Uses VS Code's native `InputBox` component with proper validation and keyboard handling

## Usage

Users can rename chat sessions by:
1. **Right-clicking** on any local chat session and selecting "Rename"
2. **Pressing F2** while a chat session is selected
3. **Using the command palette** to search for "Rename" in the Chat category

The rename experience now matches VS Code's file explorer, providing a consistent and familiar user experience throughout the interface.

## Files Changed

- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatSessionActions.ts` - Updated action to support inline editing
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatSessions.ts` - Enhanced renderer and view for inline editing mode
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chat.contribution.ts` - Action registration

title: edit-inline2 stests with TS in copilot are very very slow
body:
Not sure who is the right owner of this sorry. Today I've been trying to make a small change to the base prompt and update our cache. Running tests in series because I was getting OOM issues otherwise, the inline edit tests that require TypeScript can take a _super_ long time, sometimes 10 minutes each

```
  ▲ [ 3 ->  5] edit-inline2 [inline] [typescript] - issue #3759: add type (6m33s) (️️️💸 cache miss)
  ▼ [ 5 ->  0] edit-inline2 [inline] [typescript] - issue #404: Add a cat to a comment (5m14s) (️️️💸 cache miss)
  ▼ [10 ->  9] edit-inline2 [inline] [typescript] - issue #405: "make simpler" query is surprising (10m1s) (️️️💸 cache miss)
```

I also ran into the issue that I hit before in one repo where I had a tsconfig in my `~/Github` directory (a parent of copilot-chat) and this caused the TS server to crash because it tried to pull in _every_ file in that directory. I don't know whether that's related

title: Copilot Ignores Manual Model Selection After GPT-5 Deactivation (Not a Billing Issue)

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
### **Description:**
I am experiencing a persistent issue in GitHub Copilot for VS Code where the extension ignores my manual model selection after deactivating GPT-5, and always defaults to GPT-4.1, regardless of which non-premium model I select (e.g., Claude Sonnet 4, Gemini 2.5, Gemini Flash 2.0).

**### Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Start with GPT-5 free tier active in GitHub Copilot for VS Code.
2. Use GPT-5 until the free allowance is fully exhausted.
3. Manually deactivate GPT-5 in the Copilot settings.
4. Select a different model, such as “Claude Sonnet 4,” in the Copilot model selection menu.
5. Attempt to use Copilot for code completion or chat.

**### Observed Behavior:**

- Copilot continues to send queries to GPT-5, despite manual deactivation and explicit selection of a different model.
- Once the GPT-5 free tier is exhausted, Copilot displays:
- "You have exceeded your premium request allowance. We have automatically switched you to GPT-4.1 which is included with your plan. Enable additional paid premium requests to continue using premium models."
- Copilot never switches to the selected non-premium model, and always defaults to GPT-4.1.

**### Expected Behavior:**

After GPT-5 is deactivated and a different model is selected, Copilot should consistently use the chosen model for all requests.
No queries should be sent to GPT-5 once it is manually deactivated.

### **Troubleshooting Steps Taken:**

- Restarted VS Code and my computer.
- Signed out and back into GitHub Copilot.
- Uninstalled and reinstalled the Copilot extension.
- Cleared all settings and tried on a different machine and network.
- Attempted switching to multiple non-premium models (Claude Sonnet 4, Gemini 2.5, Gemini Flash 2.0).

**_Issue persists across all environments and models tested._**

### **Additional Information:**

This issue is not related to billing or premium quota, as it affects all non-premium models.

Extension version: 0.30.0
VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z)
OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Modes:### **Request:**

- Please escalate this ticket to a human support engineer.
- Please clarify the intended model selection and fallback behavior, especially for non-premium models.
- Investigate if there is a backend or account configuration issue causing this behavior.
- Previous Ticket(s): [261036](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/261036#issuecomment-3174751056)

title: MCP OAuth: VS Code builds /authorize from resource origin instead of authorization server from Protected Resource Metadata

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Summary
VS Code attempts to start OAuth by constructing the /authorize URL from the MCP resource origin (e.g., http://localhost:52517/authorize) instead of using the authorization server advertised via OAuth 2.0 Protected Resource Metadata (RFC 9728). This ignores the authorization_servers entry and results in failed auth.

Environment
- VS Code: Insiders (current as of 2025-08-11)
- OS: Windows 11
- Repro also seen on Stable (per report), but Insiders still repros

Repro Steps
1. Run an MCP server at http://localhost:52517 that protects its endpoint and returns OAuth 2.0 Protected Resource Metadata at:
   GET http://localhost:52517/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource
   with contents similar to:
   {
     "resource": "http://localhost:52517",
     "authorization_servers": [
       "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/v2.0"
     ],
     "bearer_methods_supported": ["header"],
     "scopes_supported": ["api://example/read"]
   }
2. In VS Code Insiders, add this MCP server (type: http) and attempt to start it.
3. Observe the auth flow/network: VS Code tries to use the resource origin host for the /authorize endpoint (e.g., http://localhost:52517/authorize) instead of first discovering and using the authorization server’s authorization_endpoint from RFC 8414 metadata (/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server at the advertised AS host).

Expected
- After reading PRM (RFC 9728) and discovering the Authorization Server (RFC 8414), VS Code should use the authorization server’s authorization_endpoint (e.g., https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/v2.0/oauth2/v2.0/authorize), and include the resource parameter per MCP Authorization spec (RFC 8707).

Actual
- VS Code constructs /authorize from the MCP resource origin (e.g., http://localhost:52517/authorize), ignoring the authorization_servers in PRM, causing auth to fail.

Notes / Related
- #258845 fixed endpoint construction that dropped subpaths for RFC 8414, but this appears to be a different bug: choosing the wrong host for the authorize endpoint entirely.
- #258410 is about the wrong resource parameter when two MCP servers share a host; also different but related to MCP auth correctness.
- Code path referenced when investigating: src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadMcp.ts (~L160) orchestrates the auth flow; it looks like we’re not honoring the PRM-provided authorization_servers and AS discovery in some paths and instead derive /authorize from the resource origin.

Additional Info
- Repro is consistent on Insiders as of Aug 11, 2025.
- If helpful, I can provide a tiny MCP server that returns the above PRM and demonstrate the exact request sequence (including the unintended call to http://localhost:52517/authorize).

Thanks!

title: Calling `workbench.action.chat.newChat` doesn't always reset the chat on first run of a new VS Code session
body: ## Info - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.2025081101 - VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider - OS Version: MacOS Sequoia 15.6 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Any ## Description When I open Copilot chat using the following two commands, it doesn’t always actually start a new chat. Sometimes, the prompt gets added to an existing chat, which seems to reduce the likelihood of our LM tool triggering correctly. From what I can tell, this almost always happens on first run with a new VS Code session. Afterwards, `newChat` will resume working properly. I have also tried issuing an open command right before calling `newChat` because I thought that might be preventing `newChat` from working the first time, but that didn't seem to fix the issue either. ## Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a chat with Copilot (F1 > Chat: Open Chat) 2. Type any message to Copilot 3. Close the chat window 4. Install the Azure Resources extension `ms-azuretools.vscode-azureresourcegroups` 5. Ensure a fresh VS Code session by performing a reload (F1 > Developer: Reload Window) 6. Run our activity log chat command (F1 > Azure: Ask Copilot about the Azure Activity Log) This executes the code snippet shown under the description section above. ## Expected I would expect the chat to only have the generic activity log prompt referenced above. ## Actual The chat includes whatever message and response resulted from # 2 of Steps to Reproduce above.

body:
Type: Bug Steps I’ve already tried to resolve: Verified explorer.autoReveal is enabled. Confirmed explorer.openEditors.visible is set to a positive number (not hidden). Ran File: Reveal Active File in Explorer View manually via Command Palette — no effect in WSL folders. Confirmed the file is inside the open workspace folder (not outside project scope). Reset related settings in settings.json (removed overrides like autoReveal: false). Tested in a fresh workspace (new folder, new file) — works in local folders, fails in WSL. Disabled all extensions except Remote - WSL — issue persists. Tried with a clean profile (no settings/extensions) — same result. Verified Explorer is visible and not collapsed at reveal time. Rebound the command shortcut and triggered via shortcut and Command Palette — still broken in WSL. Tested in local folder on the same machine — works as expected. title: Fix MCP server sampling configuration overwrite when configuring multiple servers
body:
When configuring multiple MCP servers through the "MCP: List Servers -> Configure Model Access" command, the second server's configuration would overwrite the first server's configuration instead of merging with it. This resulted in users losing their previously configured server settings.

## Root Cause

The issue was in the `_getConfig` method of `McpSamplingService`. When no existing configuration existed for a specific server, the method returned `mapping: undefined`:

```typescript
return { value: undefined, mapping: undefined, key, target: leastSpecificConfig, resource };
```

This caused the `updateConfig` method to replace the entire `chat.mcp.serverSampling` configuration section instead of merging the new server config with existing ones:

```typescript
// When mapping is undefined, this becomes { [key]: newConfig }
// instead of preserving existing server configurations
{ ...mapping, [key]: newConfig }
```

## Reproduction

1. Configure first MCP server with allowed models → Settings correctly show first server config
2. Configure second MCP server with allowed models → First server config disappears, only second server remains

## Fix

Modified `_getConfig` to return the existing mapping at the target configuration level even when no specific server config exists:

```typescript
// When no existing config is found for this server, still return the mapping
// at the target level so we can merge with existing server configurations
const targetMapping = getConfigValueInTarget(configValue, leastSpecificConfig);
return { value: undefined, mapping: targetMapping, key, target: leastSpecificConfig, resource };
```

This ensures that when updating configuration, we merge with existing server configurations rather than replacing them entirely.

## Testing

Added comprehensive unit tests that verify:
- Multiple server configurations don't overwrite each other
- Updating existing server configuration preserves other servers
- Server configuration works correctly when no previous configuration exists

Fixes #260668.

title: Workaround electron proxy issues for GitHub by allowing to switch to node's fetch
body:
A user reported that their proxy ZScaller has issues with Electron's fetch. More research needs to be done to understand why this is not playing nice wholistically...

... but, to unblock GitHub scenarios like Copilot, we add this setting to change the implementation of fetch used.

At some point, we need to have http.useElectronFetch setting be enabled by default and when that happens, this setting can be removed in favor of that.

cc @chrmarti @alexdima

title: Fix git diff completions on Windows by removing sed dependency
body:
The terminal suggest feature was failing to provide completions for `git diff` commands on Windows, showing "No suggestions" instead of file suggestions. The issue was caused by the use of Unix-specific `sed` commands that are not available on Windows.

The problem occurred in two git completion generators:

```javascript
// Before - fails on Windows
script: ["bash", "-c", "git --no-optional-locks status --short | sed -ne '/^M /p' -e '/A /p'"]

// After - cross-platform compatible  
script: ["git", "--no-optional-locks", "status", "--short"]
// with JavaScript filtering: line.match(/^M /) || line.match(/A /)
```

**Root cause:** The `getStagedFiles` and `getChangedTrackedFiles` generators used bash commands with `sed` to filter git status output. Since `sed` is not available on Windows by default, these commands would fail with errors like:

```
Error running shell command 'bash -c git --no-optional-locks status --short | sed -ne '/M /p' -e '/A /p''
```

**Solution:** Replaced sed-based filtering with cross-platform JavaScript string processing that maintains identical filtering behavior:

- `sed -ne '/^M /p' -e '/A /p'` → `line.match(/^M /) || line.match(/A /)`
- `sed -ne '/M /p' -e '/A /p'` → `line.match(/M /) || line.match(/A /)`

This change directly fixes the `git diff` completion issue since it uses the `getChangedTrackedFiles` generator to suggest modified and staged files.

**Benefits:**
- ✅ Fixes Windows compatibility issue
- ✅ No external dependencies (eliminates bash/sed requirements)
- ✅ Enhanced security (no shell command injection)
- ✅ Improved maintainability with cleaner JavaScript code
- ✅ Maintains exact same filtering logic and behavior

Fixes #261016.

title: Add Python activate hooks into shell integration scripts
body:
Resolves: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259637 

Important things to note: 
* Update all four shell integration scripts (pwsh, zsh, bash, fish) ---> Done
* Sanitize in process.ts and terminalSuggest.main.ts ---> Done
* If activate returns non-zero (failed), we should prevent crash, catch exit code, and print to terminal 
   ---> Findings: Try catch was not available for zsh, bash so using negate to prevent crash. Fish doesn't crash on eval 
   ---> Try catch was available in pwsh
   ---> Done
* Block other extension from modifying Python specific activate (Important -> Should do this as activate var is leading to code execution)  ---> Done
* Have `*` icon similar to terminal restored message. ---> Done
* Sanitize and remove hard-coded vsc python env var in terminalEnv ---> Done
* Clean-ups ---> Done?

title: add telemetry logging for todo list tool operations
Add time stamp to GitHub Copilot Chat
body: I want a timestamp for each message in the chat, it makes it easier to understand what happened when, especially when you come back to a chat days/weeks even months later. There's an old issue in the now deprecated repo that was closed as not planned but it doesn't really explain why. https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/2559 Similar but for the Terminal instead #211631 Similar but for the Output view #119916 I asked as well just to double check it hadn't been added since. I was thinking of adding a custom instruction that would append the time stamp in the meantime but that doesn't seem possible either (GPT-4.1) I guess one could always ask it to always run `date` but that seems inefficient and doesn't cover when I sent my message.
